title: The Decemberists
comment: /* Band members */ Simplified timeline, adjusted color for accessibility purposes
text:
{{short description|American indie rock band}} {{Redirect-distinguish|Decemberists|Decembrists (disambiguation){{!}}Decembrists}} {{Infobox musical artist | image = The Decemberists live in Vienna.jpg | caption = The Decemberists in 2007 | landscape = yes | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Portland, Oregon]], U.S. | genre = {{flatlist| *[[Indie rock]] *[[baroque pop]] *{{nowrap|[[indie pop]]}} *[[indie folk]] *[[alternative rock]] *[[folk rock]] *[[orchestral pop]] }} | years_active = 2000–present | label = {{flatlist| *[[Kill Rock Stars]] *[[Capitol Records|Capitol]] *[[Hush Records]] }} | website = {{URL|http://decemberists.com/|Decemberists.com}} | current_members = [[Colin Meloy]]
[[Chris Funk]]
[[Jenny Conlee]]
[[Nate Query]]
[[John Moen]] | past_members = Jesse Emerson
Ezra Holbrook
[[Rachel Blumberg]]
[[Petra Haden]] }} '''The Decemberists''' are an American [[indie rock]] band from [[Portland, Oregon]]. The band consists of [[Colin Meloy]] ([[lead vocalist|lead vocals]], [[guitar]], principal songwriter), [[Chris Funk]] (guitar, multi-instrumentalist), [[Jenny Conlee]] ([[piano]], [[keyboard instrument|keyboards]], [[accordion]]), [[Nate Query]] ([[bass guitar|bass]]), and [[John Moen]] ([[drum kit|drums]]). Their debut [[Extended play|EP]], ''[[5 Songs (The Decemberists EP)|5 Songs]]'', was self-released in 2001. Their eighth and latest full-length album ''[[I'll Be Your Girl]]'' was released on March 16, 2018, by [[Capitol Records]], and is the band's fifth record with the label. In addition to their lyrics, which often focus on historical incidents and/or folklore, the Decemberists are also well known for their eclectic live shows. [[Audience participation]] is a part of each performance, typically during encores. The band stages whimsical reenactments of sea battles and other centuries-old events, typically of regional interest, or acts out songs with members of the crowd. In 2011, the track "[[Down by the Water (The Decemberists song)|Down by the Water]]" from the album ''[[The King Is Dead (album)|The King Is Dead]]'' was nominated for Best Rock Song at the [[54th Grammy Awards]]. ==History== ===2000: Formation=== The Decemberists formed in 2000 when Colin Meloy left his band [[Tarkio (band)|Tarkio]] in Montana and moved to Portland, Oregon. There he met Nate Query, who introduced Meloy to Jenny Conlee (they had played together in the band Calobo) and the three scored a silent film together. Playing a solo show prior to meeting Query, Meloy met Chris Funk. Funk was a fan of Tarkio and played pedal steel on the first two Decemberists releases, not "officially" becoming a member until the third effort. The band's first drummer, Ezra Holbrook, was replaced by [[Rachel Blumberg]] after ''[[Castaways and Cutouts]]'', who in turn was replaced by [[John Moen]] after ''[[Picaresque (album)|Picaresque]]''. The band's name refers to the [[Decembrist revolt]], an 1825 insurrection in [[Russian Empire|Imperial Russia]]. Meloy has stated that the name is also meant to invoke the "drama and melancholy" of the month of December.{{cite news|last=Armstrong|first=Gene|date=June 17, 2004|title=On Behalf of Orangina: The Decemberists perform their dramatic, literary alt-rock, with orangina soda in tow|work=[[Tucson Weekly]]|url=https://www.tucsonweekly.com/tucson/on-behalf-of-orangina/Content?oid=1076532|access-date=October 10, 2006}} [[5 Songs (The Decemberists EP)|''5 Songs'']], the band's debut [[extended play]], was self-released in 2001. The members at that time played for several hours in a McMenamins hotel the night before to raise the money needed to record in the studio the next day. This originally served as a demo tape and the five songs on it (minus "Apology Song") were recorded in under two hours. ===2003–2005: Kill Rock Stars=== After releasing its first full record, ''[[Castaways and Cutouts]]'', on [[Hush Records]], the group moved onto the [[Kill Rock Stars]] recording label. After the re-release of ''Castaways'', ''[[Her Majesty the Decemberists]]'' was released in 2003. In 2004, the band released "[[The Tain (Decemberists album)|The Tain]]", an eighteen-and-a-half minute single track based on the [[Irish mythology|Irish mythological]] epic {{lang|ga|[[Táin Bó Cúailnge]]}}. The band's final album with Kill Rock Stars was ''[[Picaresque (album)|Picaresque]]'', which was recorded in a former church. In March 2005, the band distributed a music video via [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]], the self-produced "[[16 Military Wives]]" (from ''[[Picaresque (album)|Picaresque]]'').{{cite news | title=Rockers Flex BitTorrent's Muscle | date=March 23, 2005 | publisher=Wired News | url=http://wired-vig.wired.com/news/digiwood/0,1412,66969,00.html | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061109190719/http://wired-vig.wired.com/news/digiwood/0,1412,66969,00.html | archive-date=November 9, 2006 }} In the same month, the band's equipment trailer was stolen;{{cite news | title=Decemberists Shipwrecked By Pirates | date=March 22, 2005 | publisher=CMJ | url=http://www.cmj.com/articles/display_article.php?id=3547565 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050404101429/http://cmj.com/articles/display_article.php?id=3547565 | archive-date=April 4, 2005 }} fans contributed to a replacement fund, and another fundraiser was organized via an [[eBay]] auction, with buyers bidding for copies of ''[[Colin Meloy Sings Morrissey]]'' and original artwork by [[Carson Ellis]]. The band also received help from Lee Kruger, [[the Shins]], [[The Dandy Warhols]], and other musicians. [[C.F. Martin & Company]] offered 6- and 12-string guitars on permanent loan. In early April, police discovered the trailer and a portion of the band's merchandise in [[Clackamas, Oregon]], but the instruments and equipment were not recovered.{{cite web|last=Hunt|first=Pete|date=March 22, 2005|title=Thieves Who Took the Decemberists' Gear|url=https://www.wweek.com/portland/article-4234-thieves-who-took-the-decemberists-gear.html|website=[[Willamette Week]]}} ===2005–2006: Capitol Records debut and ''The Crane Wife''=== On December 12, 2005, Meloy revealed to [[Pitchfork Media]] that the band had signed to [[Capitol Records]], and planned to begin recording their major label debut with producers [[Tucker Martine]] and [[Chris Walla]] (of [[Death Cab for Cutie]]) in April 2006.{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Amy|date=December 12, 2005|title=Exclusive: The Decemberists Sign to Capitol Records|url=https://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/35595-exclusive-the-decemberists-sign-to-capitol-records|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026002654/https://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/35595-exclusive-the-decemberists-sign-to-capitol-records|archive-date=October 26, 2007|access-date=November 6, 2007|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]}} The band's first album on Capitol, ''[[The Crane Wife]]'', was released on October 3, 2006.{{cite web|last=Boutet|first=Chris|title=The Decemberists Tell Tales of Heart • Interviews •|url=http://exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid1=86&csid2=4&fid1=23873|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120709110415/http://exclaim.ca/Interviews/FromTheMagazine/decemberists_tell_tales_of_heart|archive-date=July 9, 2012|access-date=March 18, 2012|website=[[Exclaim!]]}} The release was accompanied by an appearance the same day on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', during which the band performed "O Valencia!". The supporting tour (called "The Rout of the Patagons Tour") began on October 17, 2006, at Portland, Oregon's [[Crystal Ballroom (Portland, Oregon)|Crystal Ballroom]]. The opening act was [[Lavender Diamond]]. Later in the tour, [[Alasdair Roberts (musician)|Alasdair Roberts]] opened for the band. In 2006, ''The Crane Wife'' was voted [[NPR]] listeners' favorite album of the year, as announced on the December 5 episode of ''[[All Songs Considered]]'',{{cite web|title=All Songs Considered|url=https://www.npr.org/programs/asc/archives/bestof06/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911194615/https://www.npr.org/programs/asc/archives/bestof06/|archive-date=September 11, 2007|access-date=July 20, 2011|publisher=[[NPR]]}} and it remains one of the Decemberists' most critically acclaimed records. In November 2006, the band encouraged fans to create a music video for the single "[[O Valencia!]]" using footage of the band in front of a green screen. On his [[Comedy Central]] [[The Colbert Report|program]], [[Stephen Colbert (character)|Stephen Colbert]] started a mock feud with the band, claiming his "green screen challenge" came first;{{cite web|last=Maher|first=Dave|date=November 30, 2006|title=Video: Stephen Colbert Vs. The Decemberists|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/25830-video-stephen-colbert-vs-the-decemberists/|access-date=June 28, 2007|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]}} the band countered that its 2005 on-stage [[lightsaber]] fight in San Francisco preceded Colbert's idea.{{cite web|last=Matthew|first=Solarski|date=November 30, 2006|title=Exclusive: Decemberists Counterchallenge Colbert!!|url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/39928-exclusive-decemberists-counterchallenge-colbert|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024184351/https://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/39928-exclusive-decemberists-counterchallenge-colbert|archive-date=October 24, 2007|access-date=June 28, 2007|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]}} The feud culminated in a December 20 guitar solo competition on Colbert's show, with lead guitarist Funk representing the band. After Colbert feigned a hand injury, [[Peter Frampton]] took over for Colbert and won an audience vote. Show guests got involved, with New York [[Governor of New York|Governor-elect]] [[Eliot Spitzer]] and Dr. [[Henry Kissinger]] declaring, "Tonight, I think the American people won." The prize for winning the challenge was revealed to be a copy of ''The Crane Wife''. According to Meloy, the Colbert challenge was not scripted, though the band was told that Frampton would step in for Colbert.{{cite web|date=January 29, 2007|title=Colin Meloy of The Decemberists|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=7061028|access-date=June 28, 2007|publisher=[[NPR]]}} ===2007: "A Bit of Grass-Stain Does Not a Ruined Pair of Jeans Make" tour=== In July 2007, the band embarked on a five-date tour with a full orchestral accompaniment. On July 7, the tour put the band on the stage of the historic [[Hollywood Bowl]] for the first time, pairing them with the [[Los Angeles Philharmonic]].{{cite magazine|last=Peters|first=Mitchell|date=April 20, 2007|title=Decemberists Get Orchestra Treatment On Tour|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1052654/decemberists-get-orchestra-treatment-on-tour|access-date=June 28, 2007|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}} On July 15, the band performed with The Mann Festival Orchestra at the [[Mann Center for the Performing Arts]] in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], where they debuted a new song.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gE6omLCtnWI Decemberists at the Mann Center in Philadelphia- New Song.] YouTube. Retrieved November 6, 2007. On July 23 with the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra at the legendary Chastain Park Amphitheater in Atlanta, Georgia. The band then played a free concert in Chicago at the [[Millennium Park]] with the [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]] Symphony Orchestra. On October 6, 2007, the band announced the cancellation of the remainder of their European tour, citing the ill health of a band member. On November 1, 2007, the band further canceled the remaining 28 shows of their "Long and Short of It" tour.{{cite web|date=November 5, 2007|title=Decemberists cancel 28 shows due to illness|url=https://www.cnn.com/2007/SHOWBIZ/Music/11/05/people.decemberists.ap/index.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071107054700/https://www.cnn.com/2007/SHOWBIZ/Music/11/05/people.decemberists.ap/index.html|archive-date=November 7, 2007|access-date=November 6, 2007|website=[[CNN]]}} ===2008: ''Always the Bridesmaid''=== The members of The Decemberists appeared, individually billed (as "[[Colin Meloy]], [[Chris Funk]], [[Jenny Conlee]], [[Nate Query]], and [[John Moen]]"), to perform in support of [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] presidential candidate [[Barack Obama]] at a rally at the [[Tom McCall Waterfront Park]] in [[Portland, Oregon]], on May 18, 2008. On October 14, 2008 the band began releasing a series of singles called ''Always the Bridesmaid''; a volume was released every month until the end of the year. The band also took up a limited tour in support of the singles, including an appearance on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]''. ===2009: ''The Hazards of Love''=== ''[[The Hazards of Love]]'' was released on March 24, 2009 on Capitol Records, under Red Light Management (Jason Colton and Ron Laffitte).{{cite web|url=http://Decemberists.com/wp-content/uploads/Dcmbr_WebPDFBook.pdf|title=The Hazards of Love (The Decemberists, cover art) at Decemberists.com|publisher=Capitol Records|year=2009}} It was made available for download on iTunes one week earlier, on March 17, 2009. The track "The Rake's Song" was put up for download on The Decemberists website in advance of the album's release. During Meloy's 2008 U.S. tour, he played several new songs that were included on the album. The album was produced by Tucker Martine.{{cite web|last=Maddux|first=Rachael|date=October 16, 2008|title=Decemberists' Colin Meloy talks Hazards of Love|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2008/10/colin-meloy-talks-new-decemberists-album-with-past.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170401055806/https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2008/10/colin-meloy-talks-new-decemberists-album-with-past.html|archive-date=April 1, 2017|access-date=July 20, 2011|website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]}} In a post on ''[[Rolling Stone]]'''s "Rock 'n' Roll Daily" blog, the band revealed more details about the album. The original plan was for ''The Hazards of Love'' to be a staged musical. However, it seems that the story was "unstageable" in such a format. Instead the band played the entire album start to finish at each concert on the spring tour.{{cite magazine|date=November 18, 2008|title=In the Studio: The Decemberists Return With Fairy-Tale Album|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2008/11/18/in-the-studio-the-decemberists-return-with-fairy-tale-album/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081212183958/http://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2008/11/18/in-the-studio-the-decemberists-return-with-fairy-tale-album/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 12, 2008|access-date=July 20, 2011|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]}} A press release read: "The album began when Meloy – long fascinated by the [[British folk revival]] of the 1960s – found a copy of revered vocalist [[Anne Briggs]]'s 1966 EP, titled ''[[The Hazards of Love (EP)|The Hazards of Love]]''. Since there was no actual song with the album’s title, he set out to write one, but was soon immersed in something much larger. ''The Hazards of Love'' tells the tale of a woman named Margaret; her shape-shifting lover, William; his fey forest queen mother; and a cold-blooded, lascivious [[Rake (character)|rake]], who recounts with spine-chilling ease how he came "to be living so easy and free" in "The Rake's Song". [[Lavender Diamond]]’s [[Becky Stark]] and [[My Brightest Diamond]]’s [[Shara Nova]] deliver the lead vocals for the female characters, while [[My Morning Jacket]]’s Jim James, [[Robyn Hitchcock]] and [[The Spinanes]]’ Rebecca Gates appear in supporting roles. The range of sounds reflects the characters’ arcs, from the accordion's singsong lilt in “Isn’t it a Lovely Night?” to the heavy metal thunder of 'The Queen's Rebuke/The Crossing.'" On February 9, 2009, the Decemberists announced in a newsletter to fans that they would be embarking on the first leg of the "A Short Fazed Hovel" Tour 2009 starting on May 19 in Los Angeles at the Hollywood Palladium. The newsletter included a complete list of dates for the first leg of the tour ending on June 14 at the [[Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival]] in [[Manchester, Tennessee]]. On Monday April 27, the band performed a shortened version of "The Wanting Comes in Waves/Repaid" on [[The Colbert Report]]. On August 14, 2009, the Decemberists played in Pittsburgh at the [[Benedum Center]]. During the show, the band members performed a skit where they ran up and down the aisles participating in a fictitious battle at [[Fort Pitt (Pennsylvania)|Fort Pitt]]. On September 19, 2009, The Decemberists played a "lottery show", originally billed as a "by request" show,{{cite web|date=August 19, 2009|title=Decemberists playing 'By Lottery' in NYC & other new dates|url=https://www.brooklynvegan.com/decemberists-pl/|access-date=July 20, 2011|website=[[BrooklynVegan]]}} at [[Terminal 5 (venue)|Terminal 5]] in [[New York City]]. The setlist was composed of songs drawn from a large bingo turner kept on stage. The [[master of ceremonies]] for the evening was singer/songwriter [[John Wesley Harding (singer)|John Wesley Harding]] and the opening act was [[Laura Veirs]] and the Hall of Flames. The randomized setlist included "July, July!", "Yankee Bayonet (I Will Be Home Then)", "The Tain I-V", "Annan Water", "The Crane Wife 3" and "The Island/Come and See/The Landlord's Daughter/You'll Not Feel the Drowning", and an original song, as a bingo ball suggested, called "Miracle on the Hudson".{{cite web|last=Hatfield|first=Amanda|date=September 21, 2009|title=The Decemberists Lottery Show w/ Laura Veirs|url=http://www.rockscope.com/article/200/The-Decemberists-Lottery-Show-w--Laura-Veirs|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006193955/https://www.rockscope.com/article/200/The-Decemberists-Lottery-Show-w--Laura-Veirs|archive-date=October 6, 2011|access-date=July 20, 2011|website=Rockscope}}{{cite web|date=September 23, 2009|title=The Decemberists & Laura Veirs w/ lotto master John Wesley Harding @ Terminal 5 in NYC – pics & setlist|url=https://www.brooklynvegan.com/the-decemberist-27/|access-date=July 20, 2011|website=[[BrooklynVegan]]}}{{cite web|title=The Decemberists Concert Setlist at Terminal 5, New York on September 19, 2009|url=http://www.setlist.fm/setlist/the-decemberists/2009/terminal-5-new-york-ny-33d78875.html|access-date=July 20, 2011|publisher=setlist.fm}} In 2009, The Decemberists also contributed the song "Sleepless" to the AIDS benefit album ''[[Dark Was the Night (album)|Dark Was the Night]]'', which was produced by the [[Red Hot Organization]]. During their European tour in the winter of 2010, the band performed "[[The Mariner's Revenge Song]]" at the conclusion of each date. The audience was encouraged to scream as if they were being consumed by a whale mentioned in the track's narrative while the band pretended to die on stage.{{cite web|last=McCarron|first=Steven|date=March 13, 2011|title=The Decemberists|url=https://www.unfoldamsterdam.nl/music/the-decemberists/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110318151643/https://www.unfoldamsterdam.nl/music/the-decemberists/|archive-date=March 18, 2011|access-date=April 6, 2011|website=Unfold Magazine}} ===2010–2011: ''The King Is Dead'' and hiatus=== The Decemberists remained off tour as they embarked on a new studio album. On September 4, 2010, the band opened for [[Neko Case]] and the headliner, [[Bob Dylan]], the first day of the Bumbershoot Arts and Music Festival in Seattle, WA. There, they announced that they were wrapping up recording of a new album and debuted three of its tracks. ''[[The King Is Dead (album)|The King Is Dead]]'' was released on January 14, 2011, with [[Peter Buck]] of [[R.E.M.]] contributing instrumentation to three of its songs. Colin Meloy later affirmed that R.E.M. had been an inspiration during the writing and recording of some of the album's material.{{cite web|last=Thurm|first=Eric|date=February 15, 2013|title=Watch Colin Meloy, Ben Gibbard, and Peter Buck Perform R.E.M.'s "You Are The Everything"|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/watch-colin-meloy-ben-gibbard-and-peter-buck-perfo,92609/|access-date=February 26, 2013|website=[[The A.V. Club]]}} "Down by the Water", a track from the new album, was released via the band's official site on November 2, and was immediately available on iTunes as a free download. The song would later be nominated for Best Rock Song at the [[54th Grammy Awards]]. ''The King Is Dead'' debuted at No. 1 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] in the United States upon its release, the first time a Decemberists album would achieve this. As compared to the band's previous work, which was influenced by the music of the [[British folk revival]], ''The King Is Dead'' was more influenced by traditionally American genres including [[country music|country]], [[blues]], and [[Americana (music)|Americana]].{{cite web|last=Meatto|first=Keith|title=The Decemberists in January – A Review of The King is Dead|url=https://frontpsych.com/2011/01/10/the-decemberists-in-january/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110113132952/https://frontpsych.com/2011/01/10/the-decemberists-in-january/|archive-date=January 13, 2011|website=Frontier Psychiatrist}} The Decemberists' "Popes of Pendarvia World Tour" in support of ''The King Is Dead'' began with a show on January 25, 2011 at Beacon Theatre in New York City.{{cite web|last=Hudson|first=Alex|date=November 15, 2010|title=The Decemberists Reveal 2011 Tour, Play Montreal, Toronto|url=http://exclaim.ca/News/decemberists_announce_2011_tour_play_montreal_toronto/|website=[[Exclaim!]]}} The tour, which included engagements throughout the U.S., Canada, and Europe, ended on August 26 at the McMenamins Edgefield in Troutdale, Oregon.{{cite web|url=http://decemberists.com/tour-archive/?gpy=2011&gpm=3/ |title=tour-archive |publisher=Decemberists |access-date=March 18, 2012}} During the tour, on May 3, it was announced on The Decemberists' official site{{cite web|date=May 3, 2011|title=A Note from Colin and Jenny|url=http://decemberists.com/news/an-important-note-from-colin-and-jenny/|access-date=March 18, 2012|publisher=Decemberists}} that Jenny Conlee had been diagnosed with [[breast cancer]]{{cite web|last=Sheila|title=Jenny Conlee Diagnosed With Breast Cancer|url=http://www.upvenue.com/article/1361-the-decemberists-jenny-conlee-diagnosed-with-breast-cancer.html|website=UpVenue}} and would miss most of the band's remaining tour dates while receiving treatment and recovering.{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Amy|date=May 3, 2011|title=Decemberists Keyboardist Jenny Conlee Diagnosed With Breast Cancer|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/42410-decemberists-keyboardist-jenny-conlee-diagnosed-with-breast-cancer/|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]}} In support of their bandmate, the band designed a 'Team Jenny' [https://web.archive.org/web/20131203092228/http://www.yellowbirdproject.com/products/the-decemberists charity t-shirt] for the [[Yellow Bird Project]] to raise money for [[Planned Parenthood]].{{cite web|date=December 7, 2011|title=Yellow Bird Project – Team Jenny Tees|url=http://www.decemberists.com/news/yellow-bird-project-team-jenny-tees/|access-date=February 11, 2014|publisher=Decemberists}} Conlee would later make a full recovery after her cancer went into remission. Meanwhile, on April 7, 2011, the band released a music video for their song "This Is Why We Fight". Directed by Aaron Stewart-Ahn, the video depicts a band of teenagers living in a bleak, post-apocalyptic society. Disgusted with the tyrannical rule of their "king", one boy and one girl lead a splinter group away from the camp. Outraged, the king and his forces attack, but the video cuts to black before any resolution can be seen. In August, an eight-song set was released on iTunes featuring six previously released tracks and two new covers: Leonard Cohen's "Hey, That’s No Way To Say Goodbye" and the Fruit Bats' "When U Love Somebody". Later that month, a new music video was debuted for the track entitled "Calamity Song". The video depicts a game, played on a tennis court by children, of simulated thermonuclear war as described in the "Eschaton" scene of [[David Foster Wallace]]'s novel ''[[Infinite Jest]]''.{{cite web|last=Carlin|first=Shannon|date=August 22, 2011|title=First Watch: The Decemberists, 'Calamity Song'|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/allsongs/2011/08/22/139033489/first-watch-the-decemberists-calamity-song/|publisher=[[NPR]]}} Meloy announced during the "Popes of Pendarvia" tour that the group would take a multi-year hiatus once the touring cycle was over. To cap off this period of activity, the band released the follow-up outtake EP ''[[Long Live the King (EP)|Long Live the King]]'' on November 1, 2011, as well as a live album from their tour for ''The King is Dead'' titled ''[[We All Raise Our Voices to the Air (Live Songs 04.11–08.11)]]'' on March 13, 2012. In addition, the band recorded a song for ''[[The Hunger Games (film)|The Hunger Games]]'' soundtrack, called "One Engine". The soundtrack, ''[[The Hunger Games: Songs from District 12 and Beyond]]'', was released on March 20, 2012. While on hiatus, the group's only activity as The Decemberists was a cameo appearance on the 7th episode in the 24th season of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', in which the band was rendered in the show's traditional style of animation and presented as the hip, new music teachers of Springfield Elementary. As well, the episode's theme music was performed with the signature folk flair of The Decemberists. ===2014–2015: ''What a Terrible World, What a Beautiful World'' === During a solo tour in 2013, Meloy announced that The Decemberists would end their hiatus and begin working on a new album within the next year. The hiatus officially concluded on March 5, 2014, with the announcement of two headlining shows at Portland's Crystal Ballroom, the band's first shows in three years, where they played their debut album, ''[[Castaways and Cutouts]]'', in its entirety.{{cite magazine|last=Reed|first=Ryan|date=March 5, 2014|title=The Decemberists Announce First Headlining Concert in 3 Years|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/the-decemberists-will-play-first-headlining-concert-in-3-years-20140305|access-date=January 14, 2015|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]}}{{cite magazine|last=Rutherford|first=Kevin|date=March 5, 2014|title=The Decemberists Returning for Benefit Show|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5923214/the-decemberists-returning-for-benefit-show|access-date=January 14, 2015|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}} On April 24, further establishing their return, the band performed on the Season 6 finale of the [[NBC]] comedy series ''[[Parks and Recreation]]''.{{cite web|last=Eakin|first=Marah|date=February 24, 2014|title=The Decemberists are also going to be on Parks And Recreation|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/the-decemberists-are-going-to-be-on-parks-and-recr-201416|access-date=January 14, 2015|website=[[The A.V. Club]]}} Additionally, The Decemberists were the mystery band for the 2014 [[Boston Calling Music Festival]], where they played on Saturday, May 24.{{cite web|url=http://bostoncalling.com/|title=Home – Boston Calling Music Festival|website=Boston Calling Music Festival|access-date=January 14, 2015}} On November 3, 2014, "Make You Better", The Decemberists' first single off the new album, was released,{{cite web|url=https://play.spotify.com/album/4KRVQOu9ANkYl9RmexLCZV|title=Spotify|publisher=Spotify|access-date=January 14, 2015}} and on January 20, 2015, the band's seventh studio album, ''[[What a Terrible World, What a Beautiful World]]'', was released.{{cite web|title=New beautiful record out in January!|url=http://www.carsonellis.com/post/100845085006/new-beautiful-record-out-in-january|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150101083506/https://www.carsonellis.com/post/100845085006/new-beautiful-record-out-in-january|archive-date=January 1, 2015|access-date=January 14, 2015|publisher=Carsonellis.com}}{{cite web|date=October 31, 2014|title="Make You Better" (Trailer) – The Decemberists|url=http://www.decemberists.com/news/make-you-better-trailer/|access-date=January 14, 2015|publisher=Decemberists}} To commemorate both the release of the new album and the Decemberists' success as a whole, January 20 was officially declared "Decemberists Day" in the group's hometown of [[Portland, Oregon]], by mayor [[Charlie Hales]].{{cite web|last=Greenwald|first=David|date=January 12, 2015|title=January 20 named Decemberists day in Portland; free show at City Hall|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/music/index.ssf/2015/01/january_20_decemberists_day_portland.html|access-date=February 18, 2015|website=[[The Oregonian]]}} In support of the album, The Decemberists made late-night appearances on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' and ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'', and on February 11, embarked on a European tour which included dates in Ireland, the UK, The Netherlands, Belgium, Switzerland, Germany, and Italy. A North American tour began on March 21, 2015, in the band's hometown of Portland, Oregon.{{cite web|url=http://www.decemberists.com/tour-archive/|title=The Decemberists: Tour Dates|publisher=Decemberists|access-date=April 7, 2015}} On October 9, 2015, The Decemberists released a five-track EP compiled from leftover tracks recorded during the ''What a Terrible World, What a Beautiful World'' sessions entitled ''[[florasongs]]''.{{cite web|date=September 11, 2015|title=New EP, florasongs, Coming October 9th|url=http://www.decemberists.com/news/new-ep-florasongs-coming-october-9/|access-date=July 7, 2016|publisher=Decemberists}} ===2017–2018: ''Offa Rex''=== A collaborative album titled ''[[The Queen of Hearts (album)|The Queen of Hearts]]'' with UK folk artist [[Olivia Chaney]] was released under the name ''Offa Rex'' on Nonesuch Records on July 14, 2017. The album is composed mainly of versions of traditional and British folk revival songs from the 1970s. U.S. tour dates were announced for July and August 2017. In late 2017, the band contributed "Ben Franklin's Song", with lyrics by ''[[Hamilton (musical)|Hamilton]]'' creator [[Lin-Manuel Miranda]], to Miranda's monthly "Hamildrops". ===2018–present: ''I'll Be Your Girl''=== On January 17, 2018, the band announced the new album ''[[I'll Be Your Girl]]'', released on March 16. The album is produced by [[John Congleton]] and was accompanied by a tour.{{cite web|date=January 17, 2018|title=New Album Coming in March, World* Tour Announced|url=http://www.decemberists.com/2018/01/17/ill-be-your-girl/|access-date=May 18, 2018|website=Decemberists}} On August 14, the band's concert at [[Prospect Park Bandshell]] (part of the BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn Festival) was broadcast live on [[WFUV]].{{cite web|last=Holland|first=Eric|date=August 15, 2018|title=The Decemberists: BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn 2018|url=http://www.wfuv.org/content/the-decemberists-bric-celebrate-brooklyn-2018|access-date=January 17, 2019|website=[[WFUV]]}}{{cite web|date=August 15, 2018|title=The Decemberists played 'The Crane Wife' in full for Celebrate Brooklyn! finale (pics, setlist, video)|url=http://www.brooklynvegan.com/the-decemberists-played-the-crane-wife-in-full-for-celebrate-brooklyn-finale-pics-setlist-video/|access-date=January 17, 2019|website=[[BrooklynVegan]]}} Along with newer material, the band performed ''[[The Crane Wife]]'' in its entirety. On December 14 of that year, they released an EP, ''Traveling On''.{{cite web|date=November 15, 2018|title=The Decemberists – Traveling on EP|url=http://www.decemberists.com/2018/11/15/the-decemberists-traveling-on-ep/|access-date=January 10, 2019|website=Decemberists}} ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' highlighted that the band had planned a 2020 tour for their twentieth anniversary, however, it "was bumped to 2021 before being canceled outright".{{Cite web |last=Hussey |first=Allison |date=January 25, 2022 |title=The Decemberists Announce 2022 Summer Tour |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/the-decemberists-announce-2022-summer-tour/ |access-date=June 24, 2022 |website=Pitchfork |language=en-US}} The group celebrated their twentieth anniversary with a series of [[Streaming media|streamed]] concerts in April 2021.{{cite web|date=March 25, 2021|title=The Decemberists - 20th Anniversary Celebration Streaming Shows|url=http://www.decemberists.com/uncategorized/20th-anniversary-celebration-streaming-shows/|access-date=April 25, 2021|website=Decemberists}}{{Cite web |date=2021-03-25 |title=The Decemberists Announce 3 Streaming Concerts After Canceling Summer Tour |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/music/decemberists-streaming-concerts-20th-anniversary-tour-canceled-colin-meloy/ |access-date=2022-06-24 |website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |language=en}} The Decemberists have announced an upcoming North American tour, titled ''Arise From The Bunkers'', scheduled for August 2022.{{Cite web |date=2022-01-26 |title=The Decemberists announce North American tour for August 2022 |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/the-decemberists-announce-north-american-tour-for-august-2022-3146525 |access-date=2022-06-24 |website=NME |language=en-GB}} ==Musical style== [[File:The Decemberists at Yale, 28 April 2009 - 76.JPG|thumb|left|Conlee playing accordion, with other keyboard instruments nearby]] The group's songs range from upbeat pop to instrumentally lush ballads, and often employ instruments like the [[accordion]], [[keyboard instrument|keyboards]], and [[Double bass|upright bass]]. In its lyrics, the band eschews the introspection common to modern rock, instead favoring a [[storytelling]] approach, as evidenced in songs such as "My Mother Was a Chinese Trapeze Artist" from the ''[[5 Songs (The Decemberists EP)|5 Songs]]'' EP and "[[The Mariner's Revenge Song]]" on ''[[Picaresque (album)|Picaresque]]''. The band's songs convey tales ranging from whimsical ("The Sporting Life", "Apology Song") to epic ("[[The Tain (Decemberists album)|The Tain]]") to dark ("Odalisque", "The Rake's Song") to political ("16 Military Wives", "[[Valerie Plame]]"), and often invoke historical events and themes from around the world ("Yankee Bayonet", "Shankill Butchers"). Their musical style has been described as [[indie rock]],{{cite news|last=Wise|first=Brian|date=June 24, 2007|title=Segue From 'Gigi' to Geek-Chic Rock|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/24/arts/music/24wise.html|access-date=February 3, 2008}} [[baroque pop]], [[indie pop]],{{cite web|last=Seida|first=Linda|title=The Decemberists {{!}} Biography & History|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-decemberists-mn0000787579/biography|access-date=January 17, 2021|website=[[AllMusic]]}} [[indie folk]],{{cite web|last=Classen|first=Allen|date=May 7, 2014|title=Gasco Building lovers gear up to save 'industrial cathedral'|url=https://nwexaminer.com/gasco-building-lovers-save|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181001142505/https://nwexaminer.com/gasco-building-lovers-save|archive-date=October 1, 2018|access-date=October 1, 2018|website=NW Examiner}} [[alternative rock]], [[folk rock]], and [[orchestral pop]].{{cite web|last=DeRogatis|first=Jim|author-link=Jim DeRogatis|date=November 5, 2006|title=Positively Prog|url=http://www.jimdero.com/News%202006/Decemberists.htm|access-date=January 17, 2021|website=www.jimdero.com}} The band's 2009 release, ''The Hazards of Love'', supplemented their usual folk and alternative style with [[progressive rock]] and [[Heavy metal music|metal]].{{Cite web|date=2015-01-08|title=The Decemberists' Colin Meloy on chart success and chicken feed|url=http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jan/08/decemberists-colin-meloy-new-album-tour-interview|access-date=2021-08-24|website=The Guardian|language=en}} ===Influences and character=== On their website, the group claim that their official drink is [[Orangina]], that they love the [[video game]] ''[[BioShock]]'' and "adore" the bands [[Norfolk & Western (band)|Norfolk & Western]], [[Explosions In The Sky]], [[The Postal Service]], [[The Long Winters]], [[Death Cab for Cutie]], [[Dokken]], [[Tycho (musician)|Tycho]], [[El Ten Eleven]], [[The Shins]], [[The Octopus Project]], [[Electrelane]], [[Camera Obscura (band)|Camera Obscura]], [[Clearlake (band)|Clearlake]], [[The Thermals]], [[Modest Mouse]], [[Swords (band)|Swords]] and [[Earlimart (band)|Earlimart]]. The band's official biography, keeping up their reputation for grandiloquence, also describes how they met in a [[Turkish bath]]. A footnote following the biography claims, "The Decemberists travel exclusively by Dr. Herring's Brand [[airship|Dirigible Balloons]]." Colin Meloy has listed [[Anne Briggs]], [[Nic Jones]], and [[Shirley Collins]] – who led the 1960s [[British folk revival]] – as major influences on ''[[The Hazards of Love]]''. Meloy has also confessed a "slavish love" for [[Morrissey]], one of his principal influences, to whom he has a tattoo dedicated,{{cite web|last=Robinson|first=Tasha|date=March 31, 2009|title=The Decemberists' Colin Meloy|url=https://music.avclub.com/the-decemberists-colin-meloy-1798216134|access-date=January 17, 2021|website=[[The A.V. Club]]}} and has made "a sort of pilgrimage" to the site of the cover photograph for [[The Waterboys]]' ''[[Fisherman's Blues]]'', an album he wore "out from obsessively repeated listens."An interview of [[Mike Scott (Scottish musician)|Mike Scott]] by Colin Meloy in ''[[The Believer (magazine)|The Believer]]'', September 2007. The band has also cited their liking for [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]],{{cite web|last=Meloy|first=Colin|date=September 15, 2006|title=Decemberists|url=https://pitchfork.com/features/guest-lists/6433-decemberists/|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]}} and the pop tunes of [[R.E.M.]] and [[XTC]]. The band also draws inspiration from British and Irish folk music.{{cite web|last=Howe|first=Brian|date=October 30, 2006|title=The Decemberists|url=http://pitchfork.com/features/interviews/6471-the-decemberists/|access-date=July 20, 2011|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]}} ==Band members== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} '''Current members''' * [[Colin Meloy]] – lead vocals, rhythm guitar, bouzouki, harmonica (2000–present) * [[Chris Funk]] – lead guitar, pedal steel, dobro, mandolin, banjo, theremin, backing vocals (2000–present) * [[Nate Query]] – double bass, bass guitar, cello, backing vocals (2000–2003, 2004–present) * [[Jenny Conlee]] – keyboards, piano, organ, accordion, glockenspiel, backing vocals (2000–present) * [[John Moen]] – drums, backing vocals (2005–present) '''Current touring musicians''' * Lizzy Ellison – backing vocals, guitar, keyboards, banjo (2022–present){{cite web | url=http://utahconcertreview.com/slc-twilight-the-decemberists/ | title=SLC Twilight: The Decemberists | date=15 August 2022 }} {{col-2}} '''Former members''' * Ezra Holbrook – drums, backing vocals (2000–2002) * [[Rachel Blumberg]] – drums, backing vocals (2002–2005) * Jesse Emerson – bass guitar, double bass, backing vocals (2003–2004) * [[Petra Haden]] – violin, backing vocals (2005–2006; touring musician 2004–2005) '''Former touring musicians''' * [[Sara Watkins]] – fiddle, guitar, backing vocals (2011) * [[Nora O'Connor|Nora O'Connor Kean]] – backing vocals, guitar (2014–2020) * [[Kelly Hogan]] – backing vocals, percussion (2016–2020) {{col-end}} '''Timeline''' {{#tag:timeline| ImageSize = width:900 height:auto barincrement:23 PlotArea = left:110 bottom:135 top:10 right:10
